meanings.definition: To cause division or disagreement between people or groups.
meanings.sent1: Her strong opinions on the topic were polarising the team.
meanings.sent2: The controversial decision was polarising the community.
meanings.sent3: The debate over the best pizza toppings was polarising the party guests.
meanings.sent4: His radical ideas were polarising the entire school.
meanings.sent5: The political candidate's speech was so polarising that it split the audience in half.

meanings.definition: Having or relating to poles or extremities.
meanings.sent1: The magnet had a polarising effect on the nearby objects.
meanings.sent2: The scientist studied the polarising properties of the crystal.
meanings.sent3: The polarising ends of the battery were clearly marked.
meanings.sent4: The polarising forces of nature were evident in the storm.
meanings.sent5: The polarising colors of the sunset painted the sky in vibrant hues.

meanings.definition: To cause light waves to vibrate in a particular direction.
meanings.sent1: The special filter polarises the light for better visibility.
meanings.sent2: The sunglasses polarise the sunlight to reduce glare.
meanings.sent3: The photographer used a polarising lens to capture the perfect shot.
meanings.sent4: The polarising effect of the mirror enhanced the room's brightness.
meanings.sent5: The polarising film on the window blocked out harmful UV rays.
